This content is for internal CRA use only. It was developed to help CVB employees to easily find court cases relevant to their analysis and research.

Court decisions on employment status and incorporated employees

You may be looking for:

  • Employment status: Employee or self-employed, including conditions for employees operating a personal services business (PSB)

You can review prior court decisions to help determine whether the worker is an employee or a self-employed worker, and if they are an employee, whether they are considered to be an incorporated employee (operating a personal services business (PSB)) for tax purposes

You must keep in mind that specific court decisions and their outcomes may vary.

The PLS team within BCD does not guarantee that the list of court cases is 100% complete. This is a new list, send your feedback to the PLS team to help improve it.

Filter
Personal services business (PSB)
General
Factors

Reset

Filter by key words:     Showing out of court cases

  • Title: AFB Janitorial Services Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Administrative and support, waste management and remediation services
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 94
    • File number(s): 2021-126(CPP), 2021-143(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Payette c. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Finance and insurance
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 9
    • File number(s): 2018-1773(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Balatoni v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Accommodation and food services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 84
    • File number(s): 2022-125(EI), 2022-126(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Hachulla v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Construction
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 63
    • File number(s): 2020-1116(EI), 2020-1579(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: 0808498 BC Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 53
    • File number(s): 2019-2421(CPP), 2019-2422(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Self-employed worker

    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2023 TCC 40
    • File number(s): 2019-1387(EI), 2019-1388(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

  • Title: Syndicat des copropriétaires le Sommet Entre Ville et Montagnes c. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Other services, except
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Acts: Employment Insurance Act, Civil Code of Québec
    • Reference: 2022 TCC 167
    • File number(s): 2019-2136(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker works at the payer's workplace

    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

    • Industry: Information and cultural industries
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2022 TCC 107
    • File number(s): 2018-777(EI), 2018-778(CPP)

    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace

    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer

    Worker is personally at risk of loss

  • Title: 7547978 Canada Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2021 TCC 7
    • File number(s): 2017-2188(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Anderson v. Minister of National Revenue

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Finance and insurance
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2021 TCC 28
    • File number(s): 2018-271(EI), 2018-272(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Insurance Institute of Ontario v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Educational services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2020 TCC 69
    • File number(s): 2019-2877(EI), 2019-2878(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Bosveld v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2020 TCC 2
    • File number(s): 2018-2611(CPP), 2018-2612(EI), 2018-2613(CPP), 2018-2614(EI), 2018-2615(CPP), 2018-2616(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

    • Court: Tax Court of Canada

    • Reference: 2020 TCC 10
    • File number(s): 2019-1010(EI)

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer

    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

  • Title: European Staffing Inc. v. Canada (National Revenue) (multiple rulings - Simoiu)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Manufacturing
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2020 FCA 219
    • File number(s): A-144-19

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: European Staffing Inc. v. Canada (National Revenue) (multiple rulings - Simoiu)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Manufacturing
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2020 FCA 219
    • File number(s): A-144-19

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Employee

  • Title: European Staffing Inc. v. Canada (National Re venue) (multiple rulings - Pajecki)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2020 FCA 219
    • File number(s): A-144-19

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work

    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: European Staffing Inc. v. Canada (National Revenue) (multiple rulings - Keshmiri)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2020 FCA 219
    • File number(s): A-144-19

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker works at the payer's workplace

    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done

  • Title: Arora Trading Ltd. v. The Queen

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business) Special circumstances
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Wholesale trade
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 98
    • File number(s): 2015-5258(IT)G

    Summary of court case

    • Tax year 2010

      Worker was operating a personal service business

    • Tax year 2009

      Worker did not have employees and was not operating a personal service business.

  • Title: Portes & Fenêtres Abritek Inc. c. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Manufacturing
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 96
    • File number(s): 2017-4148(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Victoria's Five Star Cleaning Ltd. v. MNR

    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss

  • Title: European Staffing Inc. v. MNR (multiple rulings - Bennett)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Manufacturing
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 59
    • File number(s): 2017-383(CPP), 2017-385(EI), 2018-3794(EI), 2018-3798(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Storrs v. MNR (multiple rulings - 2015)

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 38
    • File number(s): 2017-3444(EI), 2017-3445(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: AE Hospitality Ltd. v. MNR (Wait Staff - multiple)

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Accommodation and food services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 116
    • File number(s): 2015-1919(EI), 2015-1920(CPP), 2016-3767(CPP), 2016-3768(EI), 2016-3781(CPP), 2016-3782(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: AE Hospitality Ltd. v. MNR (Chefs - multiple)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Accommodation and food services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2019 TCC 116
    • File number(s): 2015-1919(EI), 2015-1920(CPP), 2016-3767(CPP), 2016-3768(EI), 2016-3781(CPP), 2016-3782(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment

    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2018 TCC 153
    • File number(s): 2011-3612(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Worker determines what work is to be done

    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment

    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Industry: Transportation and warehousing

    • Reference: 2015 TCC 340
    • File number(s): 2015-1041(EI)

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done

    Worker is personally at risk of loss

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Educational services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2015 TCC 270
    • File number(s): 2014-1966(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Quinte Children's Homes Inc. v. MNR

    • Court: Tax Court of Canada

    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2015 TCC 250
    • File number(s): 2014-674(EI), 2014-675(CPP)

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Worker determines what work is to be done

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)

    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Construction
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2015 TCC 201
    • File number(s): 2012-1349(IT)G

    Worker was self-employed and worker was not operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: G & J Muirhead Holdings Ltd. v. The Queen

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business)
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2014 TCC 49
    • File number(s): 2013-1935(IT)I

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: 1165632 Ontario Ltd. v. The Queen

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2014 TCC 189
    • File number(s): 2013-3068(IT)I, 2013-3069(IT)I

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2012 TCC 214
    • File number(s): 2011-3341(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

  • Title: Caropreso v. The Queen

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2012 TCC 212
    • File number(s): 2011-3105(IT)I

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2011 TCC 9
    • File number(s): 2010-103(EI)

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Employee

    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2011 TCC 422
    • File number(s): 2010-503(IT)I

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Jacques v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2011 TCC 414
    • File number(s): 2011-556(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Powertrend Electric Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Utilities
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2011 TCC 361
    • File number(s): 2010-372(EI), 2010-373(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Aniger Consulting Inc. v. The Queen

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business) Special circumstances
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2010 TCC 637
    • File number(s): 2007-4187(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Decision was overturned in the FCA reference 2011 FCA 349 and worker was not operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker

  • Title: Oldham Robinson Integrated Technologies Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2010 TCC 596
    • File number(s): 2009-3049(EI), 2009-3050(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

  • Title: S K Manpower Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2010 TCC 584
    • File number(s): 2009-1078(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace

    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)

    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2010 TCC 166
    • File number(s): 2004-24(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Merchants of Green Coffee Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Wholesale trade
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2010 TCC 151
    • File number(s): 2009-2786(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • File number(s): A-510-08

    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Wyseman v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Finance and insurance
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2009 TCC 512
    • File number(s): 2008-3139(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Construction
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2009 TCC 203
    • File number(s): 2006-2196(EI), 2006-2197(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Vandervelde v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Administrative and support, waste management and remediation services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2009 TCC 200
    • File number(s): 2008-1877(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

  • Title: Robertson v. The Queen

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2009 TCC 183
    • File number(s): 2007-95(IT)G

    Worker was self-employed and worker was not operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    • Result: Self-employed worker

    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2008 TCC 490
    • File number(s): 2007-1256(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Millard v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Information and cultural industries
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2008 TCC 353
    • File number(s): 2008-133(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: 489599 B.C. Ltd v. The Queen

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2008 TCC 332
    • File number(s): 2006-1940(IT)G

    Worker was self-employed and worker was not operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Number of full-time employees
    Corporation has more than 5 full-time employees throughout the year

  • Title: Logitek Technology Ltd. v. MNR

    • Reference: 2008 TCC 331
    • File number(s): 2006-2748(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: 3105822 Canada Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2008 TCC 305
    • File number(s): 2007-771(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2007 TCC 591
    • File number(s): 2007-1255(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Domart Energy Services Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Transportation and warehousing
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2007 TCC 585
    • File number(s): 2006-13(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

  • Title: Caluori v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Manufacturing
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2007 TCC 490
    • File number(s): 2006-3241(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2007 TCC 138
    • File number(s): 2006-1909(IT)I

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: National Capital Outaouais Ski Team v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2007 TCC 123
    • File number(s): 2006-2453(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker works in mobile locations

    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business)
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2006 TCC 20
    • File number(s): 2002-4205(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Royal Winnipeg Ballet v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker Special circumstances
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act, Taxation
    • Reference: 2006 FCA 87
    • File number(s): A-443-04

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: City Water International Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Federal Court of Appeal
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act, Taxation
    • Reference: 2006 FCA 350
    • File number(s): A-487-05, A-488-05, A-489-05, A-490-05, A-491-05, A-492-05

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment

    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)

    Reimbursement (factor 5)

    • File number(s): 2004-2536(CPP)

    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    • Worker works from home or their own office

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment

    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2005 TCC 452
    • File number(s): 2004-3597(EI)

    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: W. B. Pletch Company Limited v. The Queen

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business)
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Professional, scientific and technical services
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2005 TCC 400
    • File number(s): 2002-3536(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)

    Payer does not provide the worker with training

    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Woodland Insurance Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Finance and insurance
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2005 TCC 385
    • File number(s): 2004-2983(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Waverley Amateur Athletic Assn. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2005 TCC 375
    • File number(s): 2004-1265(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Industry: Public administration

    • Reference: 2005 TCC 370
    • File number(s): 2004-159(EI), 2004-160(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Williams v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Health care and social assistance
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 839
    • File number(s): 2004-881(EI), 2004-882(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Létourneau v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 81
    • File number(s): 2003-1179(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2004 TCC 755
    • File number(s): 2003-3050(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Oshawa Coiffures Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Other services, except
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 616
    • File number(s): 2002-3923(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 59
    • File number(s): 2003-822(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses
