    • Reference: 2004 TCC 555
    • File number(s): 2003-1342(CPP)

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer

    • Payer determines what work is to be done

    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)

    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: PRW Graphic Group Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Other services, except
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 31
    • File number(s): 2003-611(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

  • Title: Todman v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Construction
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 30
    • File number(s): 2003-2739(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Dodds v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Information and cultural industries

    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 29
    • File number(s): 2003-904(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Dynamic Industries Ltd. v. The Queen

    • Result: Incorporated employee (personal services business) Special circumstances
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction
    Summary
    • Act: Income Tax Act
    • Reference: 2004 TCC 284
    • File number(s): 2002-1707(IT)G

    Worker was operating a personal service business.

    Decision was overturned in the FCA reference 2005 FCA 211 and worker was not operating a personal service business.

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2004 TCC 263
    • File number(s): 2003-3773(EI)

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer

    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: World Internet Broadcasting Network Corp. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Information and cultural industries
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2003 TCC 716
    • File number(s): 2002-3098(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

  • Title: Overhead Door of Prince Albert Ltd. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Wholesale trade
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2003 TCC 709
    • File number(s): 2002-3189(CPP), 2002-3860(CPP), 2002-3868(CPP), 2002-3870(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Reference: 2003 TCC 635
    • File number(s): 2002-1464(EI)

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Budget Propane Corp. v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Retail trade
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2003 TCC 382
    • File number(s): 2000-523(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2003 TCC 178
    • File number(s): 2001-3288(EI)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: 821743 Ontario Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Other services, except
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2003 TCC 168
    • File number(s): 2002-3111(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Reber v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Construction
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2001 TCC
    • File number(s): 2000-975-CPP

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Academy of Artisans v. MNR

    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done

    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss

  • Title: American Income Life Insurance Co. v. Minister of National Revenue (Jerry Jahraus and Camille Burbank)

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Finance and insurance
    Summary
    • Acts: Canada Pension Plan, Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 2001 TCC
    • File number(s): 2001-3601(EI), 2001-3602(CPP), 2001-4483(EI), 2001-4485(CPP)

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Both worker and payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Factor not relevant to the decision
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

  • Title: Tiger Courier Inc. v. MNR

    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Transportation and warehousing
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2001 TCC
    • File number(s): 2000-1639-CPP

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Supreme Court of Canada
    • Industry: Wholesale trade
    Summary
    • Act: Criminal law
    • Reference: 2001 SCC 59
    • File number(s): 27820

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Worker determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Payer does not provide the worker with training

  • Title: Saunders (cob) VMS Management v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Act: Canada Pension Plan
    • Reference: 2000 TCC
    • File number(s): 1999-4633-EI, 1999-4634-CPP, 1999-4639-EI, 1999-4640-CPP

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Reimbursement (factor 5)

  • Title: Restaurants Masalit Inc. v. MNR

    • Result: Self-employed worker
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Accommodation and food services
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 1999 TCC
    • File number(s): 98-861-UI

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Worker sets their own hours and schedule
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works in mobile locations
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer imposes a dress code or requires a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Worker owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment

    Employee and employer
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker has freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker does not have the right to refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works from home or their own office
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer provides the worker with training

    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Other services, except
    • Industry: Public administration
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 1999 TCC
    • File number(s): 97-101-CPP, 97-897-UI

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker can delegate or subcontract work without notifying the payer
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses

    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Factor not relevant to the decision

  • Title: Puri v. MNR

    • Result: Employee
    • Court: Tax Court of Canada
    • Industry: Arts, entertainment and recreation
    Summary
    • Act: Employment Insurance Act
    • Reference: 1998 TCC
    • File number(s): 96-2519-UI, 96-2520-UI

    Summary of court case

    Intent (factor 1)
    Self-employed worker
    Control (factor 2)
    • Worker does not have freedom to determine how work should be done
    • Worker can accept or refuse work from the payer
    • Payer sets hours and schedule for the worker
    • Worker is not monitored or supervised by the payer
    • Worker works at the payer's workplace
    • Payer determines what work is to be done
    • Payer does not impose a dress code or does not require a uniform
    • Payer does not provide the worker with training
    Ownership of tools (factor 3)
    Both the worker and the payer owns the most important tools or equipment
    Subcontracting of work (factor 4)
    Worker cannot delegate or subcontract work
    Risk (factor 5)
    Worker is not personally at risk of loss
    Reimbursement (factor 5)
    Worker is not reimbursed for work-related travel expenses
